title: Unit 9 Checkpoint: Probability & Statistics
description: Assessment covering counting principles, permutations and combinations, probability rules (addition, multiplication, complement), conditional probability, binomial probability, and normal distribution with the Empirical Rule.

remediationResources.focusArea: Fundamental Counting Principle and factorial computations
Distinguishing order matters vs. order doesn't matter, P(n,r) and C(n,r) formulas
Addition rule, multiplication rule, complement rule
P(A|B) formula, independence vs. mutual exclusivity
Empirical Rule, z-scores, interpreting bell curves

assessmentProblems.question: A restaurant menu offers 4 appetizers, 7 entrees, and 3 desserts. A customer orders one of each. How many different meals are possible?
(a) How many ways can 5 books be arranged on a shelf? (b) From those same 5 books, how many ways can you choose 3 to put in your bag?
A bag contains 5 red, 7 blue, and 3 yellow marbles. One marble is drawn. Find: (a) P(red or yellow), (b) P(not blue).
assessmentProblems.answer: (a) P(red or yellow) = (5+3)/15 = 8/15 (mutually exclusive, so just add). (b) P(not blue) = 1 - 7/15 = 8/15. Note: same answer because 'not blue' = 'red or yellow'.

assessmentProblems.question: In a class of 40 students, 22 are in band, 15 are in chorus, and 8 are in both. Find the probability a student is in band OR chorus.
Two cards are drawn from a standard deck without replacement. Find the probability that both are aces.
P(A) = 0.6 and P(B) = 0.5. (a) If A and B are independent, find P(A and B). (b) If P(A and B) = 0.4, find P(B|A). Are A and B independent in this case?
assessmentProblems.answer: (a) Independent: P(A and B) = 0.6 × 0.5 = 0.30. (b) P(B|A) = P(A and B)/P(A) = 0.4/0.6 = 2/3 ≈ 0.667. Since P(B|A) = 2/3 ≠ P(B) = 0.5, they are NOT independent.

assessmentProblems.question: A fair die is rolled 5 times. Find the probability of getting exactly 2 sixes.
A vaccine is 90% effective. Out of 8 vaccinated people exposed to the illness, find: (a) P(all 8 are protected), (b) P(at least 1 is not protected).
IQ scores are normally distributed with μ = 100 and σ = 15. (a) What percent of people have IQs between 70 and 130? (b) What percent have IQs above 130? (c) Find the z-score for an IQ of 124.

ANALYSIS TASK: A company ships boxes of 20 phone screens. Each screen has a 2% chance of being defective (independent of others). The company guarantees a refund if a box contains 2 or more defective screens. (a) Find P(exactly 0 defective). (b) Find P(exactly 1 defective). (c) Find P(2 or more defective) and interpret what this means for the company's refund rate.
